paragraphText: This is a narration-block, which contains a TITLE, some paragraph content (that's me!), and a link , which is shown below.
To the right (or wherever your CSS places it) is a graph area.
ScrollyTeller helps us use simple text-based triggers stored in a CSV file to trigger actions in a the graph area when a narration block hits the middle of the page and becomes active.

This narration block has a trigger called 'graph:transparent' that sets the graph opacity to 0.5.

The next one has trigger called 'graph:hide' that will set the graph opacity to 0.

When this narration block 'activates', we should see the graph disappear.

(see: onActivateNarrationFunction() in the file: demo_app/exampleSection0/ exampleSection0.js of the ScrollyTeller repo)
We can also use a progress variable (0-1) to smoothly transition things.  Here we created a trigger called 'graph:fadein' to smoothly transition the opacity of the graph in.

And if we can make a 'graph:fadein', we can make a 'graph:fadeout' to smoothly transition the opacity of the graph back out.

(see: onScrollFunction() in the file: demo_app/exampleSection0/ exampleSection0.js of the ScrollyTeller repo)
This is the last narration block in 'ExampleSection0'.  In the next section, we will look at how we can get data for a graph, then use triggers to create actions within graphs.
